Title: A nonnegative random variable has zero expectation if and only if it is zero almost surely
Content: Let $Y$ be a non-negative random variable. Prove that $E(Y) = 0$ if and only if $P(Y=0)=1$ . My understanding is that while you can prove it for discrete $Y$ , the result is true for all $Y$ .
AcceptedAnswer: If $Y$ is a non-negative random variable defined on a probability space $\Omega$ and $$E(Y) = \int_{\Omega} Y dP=0$$ then $Y = 0$ almost surely and $P(\{\omega \in \Omega: Y(\omega)=0\})=1$ . Proof: For any $m \in \mathbf{N}$ , let $$E_m = \{\omega \in \Omega:Y(\omega) > 1/m\}$$ then, since $Y$ is non-negative, we have $Y = Y1_{\Omega} \geq Y 1_{E_m}$ and then $$0 = \int_{\Omega} Y dP \geq \int_{E_m} Y dP\geq \frac1{m}P(E_m) \geq 0,$$ and $P(E_m) = 0$ . So $$0 \leq P(\{\omega \in \Omega:Y(\omega) \neq 0\})= P\left(\bigcup E_m\right) = \lim_{m \rightarrow \infty}P(E_m)=0$$ Hence $$P(\{\omega \in \Omega:Y(\omega) \neq 0\})=0 \implies P(\{\omega \in \Omega:Y(\omega) = 0\})=1 $$ QED Conversely, if $Y=0$ a.s. then $E(Y) = \int Y dP = 0$
